Color Scheme

Brand colors

Primary brand colors, used for elements that must reflect Marvel's brand.

Marvel

Primary brand color. For elements that reflect Marvel's brand, like a wordmark or icon.

Light Marvel
#85d7ff
Marvel
#1fb6ff

#009eeb

Secondary brand color. For elements that reflect Marvel's brand. Also use for decoration.

Gray colors

Gray colors, used for text, backgrounds, lines and borders.

Black

Default text color. Use for dark backgrounds in UIs or website sections.

Steel

Use for dark backgrounds in UIs or website sections to offset a "black" background.

Slate

Use for dark backgrounds in UIs or website sections to offset a "steel" background.

Silver

Light text color. Works on light or dark backgrounds. Not for any other purpose.

Smoke

Use for lines, borders, dividers or similar purposes. Not for text or backgrounds.

Smoke
#e0e6ed
Dark Smoke
#d3dce6
XDark Smoke
#c0ccda
Snow

Use for light backgrounds in UIs or website sections. Not for any other purpose.

Snow
#f9fafc
Dark Snow
#eff2f7
XDark Snow
#e5e9f2
White

Highlighted text color on dark backgrounds. For white backgrounds in UI components.

UI colors

UI colors are used for action buttons and alert messages.

Blue

For primary brand identity elements like logomarks, links and other UI elements.

Positive

For reinforcing a positive action or communicating a positive message.

Negative

For reinforcing a negative action or communicating a negative message.

Transparent colors

Transparent colors are used for modals, popovers, tooltips and borders that go on top ot things.

Blue 15%

White 98%
White 30%
White 15%
White 5%

Reversible grays

The gray colors are reversible. Each light gray color has a complementary dark gray color. The helps keep the colors well balanced and also makes it easier to implement light/dark themes.

Light theme

This subtle paragraph text color works equally well on a light or dark background.

Dark theme

This subtle paragraph text color works equally well on a light or dark background.

Typography

Typefaces

Marvel's primary typeface is Fakt Pro Rounded. We chose Fakt Pro Rounded because we needed a robust typeface with legible numbers that rendered well at small sizes. It needed to be soft and friendly, yet plain enough to get out of the way and let the user's designs shine.

Paragraph text

Marvel's default font size is 16px, which is inherited from the <body>. All paragraph text should use a <p> tag. Margins and line-heights are not shared equally across all paragraph text instances, so we set those properties separately with additional classes. Given a line length of approximately 80 characters, use .lineHeight-m.

This is paragraph text. Marvel for iOS is a quick and easy way to turn sketches and images into interactive mobile and web prototypes, without needing to code.

You can use paper to draw out your ideas and then use Marvel to take photos of your drawings or add mockups from the Creative Cloud.

                    <p class="lineHeight-m marginBottom-s">...</p>
<p class="lineHeight-m">...</p>

Medium Paragraph text

Sometimes you need a bigger font to improve legibility or communicate importance, e.g. in a blog post. We handle this by adding .fontSize-l. Given a line length of approximately 80 characters, use .lineHeight-l.

This is paragraph text. Marvel for iOS is a quick and easy way to turn sketches and images into interactive mobile and web prototypes, without needing to code.

You can use paper to draw out your ideas and then use Marvel to take photos of your drawings or add mockups from the Creative Cloud.

                    <p class="lineHeight-m marginBottom-s">...</p>
<p class="lineHeight-m">...</p>

Large paragraph text

Sometimes you need a bigger font to improve legibility or communicate importance, e.g. in a blog post. We handle this by adding .fontSize-xl. Given a line length of approximately 80 characters, use .lineHeight-xl.

This is paragraph text. Marvel for iOS is a quick and easy way to turn sketches and images into interactive mobile and web prototypes, without needing to code.

You can use paper to draw out your ideas and then use Marvel to take photos of your drawings or add mockups from the Creative Cloud.

                    <p class="fontSize-xl lineHeight-xl marginBottom-m">...</p>
<p class="fontSize-xl lineHeight-xl">...</p>

Font sizes

Use a single class to define a font size.

This text is extra extra extra large

This text is extra extra large

This text is extra large

This text is large

This text is medium

This text is small

This text is extra small

                    // For title headings in highlighted, hero sections.
<p class="fontSize-xxl">...</p>

// For primary headings or longform text.
<p class="fontSize-xl">...</p>

// Default paragraph text
<p class="fontSize-m">...</p>

// For supporting paragraph text
<p class="fontSize-s">...</p>

// For subtle text, UI hints or very small headings.
<p class="fontSize-xs">...</p>

Type tags

Text can be set in a number of different html tags - <p>, <small>, <strong>, <time>, etc. Each tag communicates a different semantic meaning but tags don't carry any aesthetic value. To order the appearance of a string of text, add additional classes.

This is semantically emphasized text which is also bold. This is semantically de-emphasized text which is also small. 
                    <strong class="fontWeight-5">...</strong>
<small class="fontSize-s">...</small>

Alignment classes

Left, right or center align text with text alignment classes.

Left aligned text

Center aligned text

Right aligned text

                    <p class="textAlign-left">...</p>
<p class="textAlign-center">...</p>
<p class="textAlign-right">...</p>

Transformation classes

Transform text with text transformation classes.

Lowercased text

Uppercased text

Capitalized text

                    <p class="textTransform-lowercase">...</p>
<p class="textTransform-uppercase">...</p>
<p class="textTransform-capitalize">...</p>

Grids

Basic grid

We use grids exclusively for layouts which require a number of columns of equal width. Grids can have 1-6 columns, specified by a class .grid--1, .grid--2, .grid--3, .grid--4, .grid--5 or .grid--6. If you need more than 6 columns, try taking a long, hard look in the mirror. There are also two grids with uneven widths which can be specified by using classes .grid--6-4 and .grid--7-3.

                    <div class="grid grid--m grid--1">
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--m grid--2">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--m grid--3">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--m grid--4">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--m grid--5">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--m grid--6">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--m grid--6-4">
  <div>...</div>

  <div>...</div>

Grid sizes

You have three grid size options to choose from, specified by a class. .grid--m is the default. .grid--l and .grid--xl are used mostly in the marketing site.

                    <div class="grid grid--m grid--2">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--l grid--2">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

<div class="grid grid--xl grid--2">
  <div>...</div>
  <div>...</div>
</div>

Page wrap

Page wrap

Page wrap is a wrapper for the whole page. There are 3 different widths, defined by an additional class .pageWrap--s, .pageWrap--m, .pageWrap--l.

                    <div class="pageWrap pageWrap--s">...</div>
<div class="pageWrap pageWrap--m">...</div>
<div class="pageWrap pageWrap--l">...</div>

Unordered list

Use <ol> with list--ordered when the list order is relevant.

  1. This is a list item
  2. This is another list item
  3. Yep, another list item
  4. This is a list item
  5. This is another list item
  6. Yep, another list item
  7. This is a list item
  8. This is another list item

</ol>

Links

Blue link

This is your go-to link. To be used on light backgrounds.

Default blue link 
                    <a class="link link--blue" href="#">...</a>

Light link

For subtle or infrequently used links. To be used on light backgrounds.

Light link 
                    <a class="link link--light" href="#">...</a>

Light link (Reversed)

For subtle or infrequently used links. To be used on dark backgrounds.

Light link reversed 
                    <a class="link link--lightReversed" href="#">...</a>

Negative link

Some links need a visual warning to prevent harmful, unintentional actions.

Negative link 
                    <a class="link link--negative" href="#">...</a>

Snow background link

This link receives a light gray background on hover. This link style is commonly used in popovers, modals and navigation menus to provide a larger click area.

Light background on hover 
                    <a class="padding-s link link--snowBg" href="#">...</a>

Colourful links

Colourful and friendly links used mainly on the blog to differenciate categories.

Buttons

Button sizes

Define a button size with .button--s, .button--m, .button--l or .button--xl. The default button size is .button--m.

                  <button class="button button--xl button--flat bg-marvel">...</button>
<button class="button button--l button--flat bg-marvel">...</button>
<button class="button button--m button--flat bg-marvel">...</button>
<button class="button button--s button--flat bg-marvel">...</button>

Flat button

Flat buttons should be used to signify necessary or mandatory actions. There are two color options, specified with an additional class .bg--marvel or .bg--positive.

Default
Positive 
                    <button class="button button--m button--flat bg-marvel">...</button>
<button class="button button--m button--flat bg-positive">...</button>

Ghost button

Ghost buttons should be used to signify optional, infrequent or subtle actions. There are three color options, specified with an additional class .bg--marvel--hover, .bg--orange--hover or .bg--negative--hover.

Default
Orange
Negative 
                    <button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-marvel--hover" type="button">...</button>

Outlined button

Outlined buttons should be used to signify optional, infrequent or subtle actions. There are three color options, specified with an additional class .bg--marvel--hover, .bg--orange--hover or .bg--negative--hover.

Default
Orange
Negative 
                    <button class="button button--m button--outlined bg-white bg-marvel--hover" type="button">...</button>

Ghost button on dark background

Ghost buttons should be used to signify optional, infrequent or subtle actions. There are three color options, specified with an additional class .bg--marvel--hover, .bg--orange--hover or .bg--negative--hover.

Default 
                    <button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-white--hover is-reversed" type="button">...</button>

Special buttons

Special buttons have different states and behaviour to the regular ones. For example, .is-sad will show a sad face on hover and is meant to be used on negative action links like deleting an account. Another special behaviour is the success button state, which will be triggered if you add .is-successful on a .button--success.

Delete Account
Create Account
Create Account Waiting
Oops this will most likely fail 
                    <button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-negative--hover is-sad" type="button">...</button>

<button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-negative--hover button--success" type="button">...</button>

Button with icon

Use a single class to define a size for your button.

Button 
                    <button class="button button--xl">
  <span class="display-inlineBlock marginRight-xs">
    <svg class="verticalAlign-middle">...</svg>
  </span>
  <span class="display-inlineBlock">...</span>
</button>

Button with lone icon

Use a single class to define a size for your button.

                    <button class="button button--xl">
  <span class="display-inlineBlock marginRight-xs">
    <svg class="verticalAlign-middle">...</svg>
  </span>
  <span class="display-inlineBlock">...</span>
</button>

Disabled button

Disabled buttons receive an .is-disabled class and a disabled attribute.

                  <button class="button button--m button--flat bg-marvel is-disabled" disabled>Button</button>

Waiting button

Waiting buttons receive an .is-loading class.

                  <button class="button button--m button--flat bg-marvel is-disabled" disabled>Button</button>

Button group

Group multiple buttons inline. Useful for action bars. Only ghost buttons should be placed in a button group.

                    <div class="buttonGroup">
  <div>
    <button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-marvel--hover"></button>
  </div>
  <div>
    <button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-marvel--hover"></button>
  </div>
  <div>
    <button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-marvel--hover"></button>
  </div>
  <div>
    <button class="button button--m button--ghost bg-marvel--hover"></button>
  </div>
</div>

Straight up textarea yo.

                    <textarea class="textarea textarea--m textarea--default"></textarea>

Textarea with icon

Straight up textarea with some pretty icon yo.

                    <textarea class="textarea textarea--m textarea--default"></textarea>

Growing textarea

This textarea looks like an input intially, but grows when focused. It is not resizeable. It usually works best with invisible input styling, though can be used with other input styling if necessary.

                    <textarea class="textarea textarea--growing textarea--invisible"></textarea>

Avatars

Basic avatar structure

Avatars display an image if the user has uploaded one but if not, initials are shown instead. The background color is pulled from ... and set inline on .avatar. The image URL is set inline on .avatar-img. Each avatar should have a title attribute which displays the user's name.

DB
DB
                    <div class="avatar avatar--m" title="Dean Blacc" style="...">
  <div class="avatar-img" style="..."></div>
  <div class="avatar-initials">...</div>
</div>

Avatar sizes

Use size classes .avatar--xs, .avatar--s, .avatar--m, .avatar--l, or .avatar--xl to set the appropriate size. The default size is medium.

DB
DB
DB
DB
DB
                    <div class="avatar avatar--xs" title="Dean Blacc" style="...">
  <div class="avatar-img" style="..."></div>
  <div class="avatar-initials">...</div>
</div>

<div class="avatar avatar--s" title="Dean Blacc" style="...">
  <div class="avatar-img" style="..."></div>
  <div class="avatar-initials">...</div>
</div>

<div class="avatar avatar--m" title="Dean Blacc" style="...">
  <div class="avatar-img" style="..."></div>
  <div class="avatar-initials">...</div>
</div>

<div class="avatar avatar--l" title="Dean Blacc" style="...">
  <div class="avatar-img" style="..."></div>
  <div class="avatar-initials">...</div>
</div>

Avatars with team icons

Append an optional .avatar-team into the avatar and set its background image in order to show that a user belongs to a team. Team icons automatically respond according to the parent avatar size.

DB
DB
DB
DB
DB
                    <div class="avatar avatar--m" title="Dean Blacc" style="...">
  <div class="avatar-img" style="..."></div>
  <div class="avatar-initials">...</div>
  <div class="avatar-team" style="..."></div>
</div>

Custom avatar sizes

Certain situations demand a custom avatar size. To handle this, add .avatar--custom and set the width and height on the parent container. Due to the variable height, you also need some extra elements to vertically center the initials.

DB
DB
                    <div style="width: 200px; height: 200px;">
  <div class="avatar avatar--custom" title="Dean Blacc" style="...">
    <div class="avatar-img" style="..."></div>
    <div class="display-table posPinTL width-100 height-100">
      <div class="display-tableCell verticalAlign-middle">
        <div class="avatar-initials">...</div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

Popovers

Basic popover structure

Popovers are used for any contextual content that shouldn't block the the user. Some common uses are dropdown link menus, hovercards, complex tooltips etc. Below are some guidelines for usage and structure:

  • Only shared styles are componentised globally. Variable styles are applied with additional classes.
  • Padding size can vary. Padding can either be applied to a <div> inside the popover element or can be applied directly to children of the popover element. The best approach depends on the structure of the content inside the popover component.
  • Popover content can vary, there are no strict dos and don'ts.
  • Popover max-widths and max-heights usually vary on a case-by-case basis. These properties are not shared globally, therefore, we set the max-width and max-height inline.
I have a top caret. 
                  <div class="popover" style="max-width: 300px;">
  <div class="padding-s">
    <span class="fontSize-s">...</span>
  </div>
  <span class="popover-tick popover-top-tick"></span>
</div>

Popover caret positions

You can move the position of the caret by swapping a single class.

I have a top caret.
I have a bottom caret.
I have a left caret.
I have a right caret. 
                  // Popover with top caret
<div class="popover">
  <div class="padding-s">
    <span class="fontSize-s">...</span>
  </div>
  <span class="popover-tick popover-top-tick">
</div>

// Popover with bottom caret
<div class="popover">
  <div class="padding-s">
    <span class="fontSize-s">...</span>
  </div>
  <span class="popover-tick popover-bottom-tick">
</div>

// Popover with left caret
<div class="popover">
  <div class="padding-s">
    <span class="fontSize-s">...</span>
  </div>
  <span class="popover-tick popover-left-tick">
</div>

// Popover with right caret
<div class="popover">
  <div class="padding-s">
    <span class="fontSize-s">...</span>
  </div>
  <span class="popover-tick popover-right-tick">
</div>

Popover with links

A simple popout menu with links, possibly used for header nav menus, filters etc.

Knowledge base Contact us Your account Sign out 
                  <div class="popover popover-list" style="max-width: 200px;">
  <div class="paddingTopBottom-xxs">
    <a href="#">...</a>
    <a href="#">...</a>
    <a href="#">...</a>
    <a href="#">...</a>
  </div>
  <span class="popover-tick popover-top-tick"></span>
</div>

Popover with separator.

Add an optional element .popover-separator as a separator between popover list elements.

Make a copy Add to folder Archive

    <div class="paddingTopBottom-xxs">
        <a href="#">...</a>
        <a href="#">...</a>
        <a href="#">...</a>
        <div class="popover-separator"></div>
        <a href="#">...</a>
    </div>
</div>

  <div class="antiscroll-inner">
    <div>...</div>
  </div>
</div>

Hide elements

Hide element completely

Hide an element from both screenreaders and browsers. The element's space will be collapsed, which explains why you can't see it below. Check dev tools if you don't believe me :)

                    <div class="hidden"></div>

Hide element visually

Hide an element visually but keep it available to screenreaders. The element's space will not be respected.

                     <div class="visuallyHidden"></div>

Hide children

Hide children of an element initially and show them hover.

Hello world
                     <div class="hideChildren">
  <div class="hideChildren-child"></div>
</div>

Text manipulation

Truncate text

When text overflows its container, truncate the text and append 3 dots.

This text overflows its parent element and therefore will be truncated and three dots will be appended.

                    <p class="truncateText">...</p>

Center elements

Horizontally center

Center an element horizontally. The element must have a width declared.

                    <div class="centered"></div>

Vertically center

Center an element vertically inside its parent. All parent elements must have a height specified.

Click and type to see how the text magically centers itself vertically in the parent container.
                    <div style="height: 300px;">
  <div class="verticallyCenter">...</div>
</div>

Layout

Clearfix

When child elements are floated, their parent element will collapse. To expand the parent again, you must clear those floats with a clearfix. Open dev tools and remove the cf class from the parent to see how the layout collapses.

                    <div class="cf">
  <div class="float-left"></div>
  <div class="float-right"></div>
</div>

Inline

Place multiple elements inline. If you need to space the elements apart, handle that with additional margin classes.

                    // Basic example without margins
<div class="inline">
  <div>
    <div class="bg-smoke"></div>
  </div>
  <div>
    <div class="bg-silver"></div>
  </div>
  <div>
    <div class="bg-steel"></div>
  </div>
</div>

// Example with margins
<div class="inline">
  <div class="marginRight-m">
    <div class="bg-smoke"></div>
  </div>
  <div class="marginRight-m">
    <div class="bg-silver"></div>
  </div>
  <div class="marginRight-m">
    <div class="bg-steel"></div>
  </div>
</div>

Positioning

Pin an element relative to its closet relative parent. Or fix an element relative to the viewport.

                    // Absolutely pin an element to its closest relative parent
<div class="position-relative">
  <div class="posPinTL"></div>
  <div class="posPinTR"></div>
  <div class="posPinBL"></div>
  <div class="posPinBR"></div>
</div>

// Fix an element to a viewport corner
<div class="posFixTL"></div>
<div class="posFixTR"></div>
<div class="posFixBL"></div>
<div class="posFixBR"></div>
